head.title: Rejoinder on Ross School: Don't Expect an Apology

hedline.hl1: Rejoinder on Ross School: Don't Expect an Apology

block.p: Desmond Ryan's diatribe against the Pine Barrens Society and Richard Amper accuses Mr. Amper of engendering mean-spirited cynicism and vitriol. Talk about the pot calling the kettle black.

Mr. Ryan, representing the Association for a Better (read ''Builders'') Long Island, berates Mr. Amper for ''putting students in the cross hairs'' in a cartoon satirizing the Ross School's expansion plans.
Desmond Ryan's diatribe against the Pine Barrens Society and Richard Amper accuses Mr. Amper of engendering mean-spirited cynicism and vitriol. Talk about the pot calling the kettle black.

Mr. Ryan, representing the Association for a Better (read ''Builders'') Long Island, berates Mr. Amper for ''putting students in the cross hairs'' in a cartoon satirizing the Ross School's expansion plans.

This is arrant nonsense. The cartoon was humorous, playful and accurate in its essence. Mr. Ryan's response, wringing his hands over a perceived slight of the students, reveals either a total lack of humor or a truly cynical use of the students as a shield for his own tired, more-building-is-better beliefs.
Making an issue of the Ross School cartoon exposes the bankruptcy of ideas in the pro-development community.
TOM CASEY Vice President Long Island Greenbelt Trail Conference Great Neck
